headline: Police contact Nasarawa as gunmen kidnap Kaduna monarch on farm
summarized_story:
Some bandits have abducted Gyet Maude, the traditional ruler of the Jaba chiefdom in the Jaba Local Government Area of Kaduna State.
The first-class-monarch, who is said to be over 80 years, was abducted on Monday on his farm in Gitata, a border town between Kaduna and Nasarawa states.
The incident came barely two after bandits’ abduction of the 85-year-old emir of Kajuru, Alhaji Alhassan Adamu, alongside 13 other members of his family.
However, in less than 24 hours, Adamu regained freedom, while other members of the family were held back by the kidnappers.
The state Police Public Relations Officer, ASP Mohammed Jalige, said the command had contacted its Nasarawa counterpart over the matter for further details.

headline: Commissioner calls for failed parents’ tribunal
summarized_story:
The Osun State Commissioner for Information and Civic Orientation, Funke Egbemode, on Monday called on the Federal Government through the National Orientation Agency to set up failed parents’ tribunal to restore traditional family values.
Egbemode, while declaring open a four-day step-down training on the elimination of child labour for staff of National Orientation Agency and media professionals in Osogbo, explained the tribunal would educate parents on the implications of mishandling of children.
She said, “Villages, towns, communities and even nations fail first from the home.
Regardless of the terminologies we have adopted to describe them, the ills in our society are the failure of parenting.
“The National Orientation Agency really needs to consider setting up failed parents’ tribunal.

Ethiopia’s Amhara region has called on all armed residents to mobilise for battle against rebels from conflict-hit Tigray, calling it a “survival campaign”, state media reported.
Amhara borders Tigray to the south, and the two regions are embroiled in a decades-old land dispute that has become central to the eight-month-old war in Tigray.
Sunday’s statement from Amhara regional president Agegnehu Teshager echoes a call made Friday by the president of Ethiopia’s Afar region just east of Tigray.
Together the two statements highlight the potential for the Tigray war, which Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed declared all but over in late November, to draw in the rest of the country.
The war has already killed thousands and, according to the United Nations, pushed hundreds of thousands into famine.

headline: Tunisia’s President Accused of ‘Coup’ after Dismissing Prime Minister
summarized_story:
Tunisia’s president has suspended parliament and dismissed Prime Minister Hichem Mechichi in a move condemned as an attack on democracy by his rivals but which others greeted with celebrations on the streets.
It is the biggest challenge yet to a 2014 constitution that split powers between the president, prime minister and parliament.
Tunisian Parliament Speaker Rached Ghannouchi accused President Saied of launching “a coup against the revolution and constitution” after the move.
Tunis-based journalist Rabeb Aloui told Al Jazeera that Saied’s move did not come as a surprise, as he had threatened to dissolve parliament and sack the prime minister.
In Tunis on Sunday, police used pepper spray against protesters who threw stones and shouted slogans demanding that Prime Minister Mechichi quit and parliament be dissolved.

headline: Covid: Fauci Says US Heading in Wrong Direction as Cases Rise
summarized_story:
Dr Anthony Fauci said the Delta variant of Covid-19 was driving the spike in areas with low vaccination rates.
The US had been a world leader in jab uptake until April, when vaccination rates started to drop off.
Vaccination rates are particularly low in southern states, where fewer than half of residents have received their first dose in some cases.
The sharpest increases in Covid cases are in states with lower vaccination rates, such as Florida, Texas and Missouri.
In his interview with CNN, Dr Fauci said local leaders in areas with low vaccination rates needed to do more to encourage people to get jabbed.
